questions.question: Why is the idea of only five senses considered a simplification?
options: Because many sensory systems operate outside awareness
Because only vision and hearing are real senses
Because taste and smell are the same sense
questions.feedback: The nervous system supports many parallel sensory channels beyond the classic five.

questions.question: A sensory system is defined as one that:
options: Detects, converts, and transmits specific stimuli
questions.feedback: Sensory systems detect stimuli, transduce them, and provide information to the brain.

questions.question: What is sensory transduction?
options: The conversion of physical stimuli into neural signals
The integration of sensory inputs in cortex
The modulation of perception by attention
questions.feedback: Transduction converts physical energy into neural activity.

questions.question: Which sense provides information about limb position without vision?
questions.feedback: Proprioception signals limb position, muscle stretch, and joint angle.

questions.question: Which sensory system monitors the internal state of the body?
questions.feedback: Interoception monitors internal variables like heart rate and hunger.

questions.question: Nociception is best described as:
questions.feedback: Nociception detects potentially damaging stimuli; pain is a perceptual construct.

questions.question: What is a receptive field?
options: The region of sensory space influencing a neuron
questions.feedback: A receptive field is the region of sensory space that affects a neuron’s activity.

questions.question: Stimulus intensity is primarily encoded by:
options: Firing rate and number of active receptors
questions.feedback: Intensity is encoded by firing rate and population recruitment.

questions.question: Which sensory system bypasses the thalamus?
questions.feedback: Olfactory signals reach cortex without a thalamic relay.

questions.question: What is the primary role of the thalamus in sensory processing?
options: Active modulation and organization of sensory signals
questions.feedback: The thalamus actively modulates sensory information.

questions.question: What property of light determines perceived color?
questions.feedback: Wavelength corresponds to perceived color.

questions.question: Human vision is sensitive to wavelengths approximately between:
questions.feedback: Human vision spans roughly 400 to 700 nm.

questions.question: Which structure contains photoreceptors?
questions.feedback: Photoreceptors are located in the retina.

questions.question: Rods are specialized for:
questions.feedback: Rods are highly sensitive and support scotopic vision.

questions.question: Cones are primarily responsible for:
questions.feedback: Cones mediate color vision and high acuity.

questions.question: Where is visual acuity highest?
questions.feedback: The fovea contains a high density of cones.

questions.question: What causes the blind spot?
questions.feedback: The optic nerve exits where no photoreceptors are present.

questions.question: Retinal ganglion cells are:
questions.feedback: Ganglion cells form the optic nerve.

questions.question: ON-center ganglion cells respond best to:
questions.feedback: ON-center cells increase firing to light in the center.

questions.question: Center–surround organization emphasizes:
questions.feedback: Center–surround fields emphasize changes and contrast.

questions.question: Which retinal axons cross at the optic chiasm?
questions.feedback: Nasal retinal axons cross to the contralateral side.

questions.question: Each hemisphere processes information from:
questions.feedback: Each hemisphere processes the contralateral visual field.

questions.question: The lateral geniculate nucleus is located in the:
questions.feedback: The LGN is a thalamic nucleus.

questions.question: V1 neurons are selective for:
questions.feedback: V1 neurons encode edges, orientation, and location.

questions.question: What does cortical magnification reflect?
questions.feedback: Important regions like the fovea occupy more cortical space.

questions.question: The ventral visual stream is primarily involved in:
questions.feedback: The ventral stream answers “what is it?”

questions.question: The dorsal visual stream is mainly involved in:
questions.feedback: The dorsal stream supports spatial processing and action.

questions.question: Prosopagnosia results from damage to:
questions.feedback: Prosopagnosia reflects ventral stream damage.

questions.question: Akinetopsia is characterized by:
questions.feedback: Akinetopsia is the inability to perceive motion.

questions.question: Which mechanoreceptor detects vibration?
questions.feedback: Pacinian corpuscles are sensitive to vibration.

questions.question: Smaller receptive fields allow:
questions.feedback: Smaller receptive fields support fine spatial discrimination.

questions.question: The dorsal column pathway carries:
questions.feedback: The dorsal column pathway carries precise touch information.

questions.question: The spinothalamic pathway primarily conveys:
questions.feedback: The spinothalamic pathway carries pain and temperature.

questions.question: Primary somatosensory cortex is located in the:
questions.feedback: S1 is located in the postcentral gyrus.

questions.question: The sensory homunculus reflects:
questions.feedback: Cortical representation reflects functional importance.

questions.question: Nociceptors are activated by:
questions.feedback: Nociceptors respond to harmful stimuli.

questions.question: Aδ fibers convey:
questions.feedback: Aδ fibers transmit fast, sharp pain.

questions.question: Pain processing involves:
questions.feedback: Pain has sensory, emotional, and cognitive components.

questions.question: Sound frequency is perceived as:
questions.feedback: Frequency corresponds to perceived pitch.

questions.question: Sound amplitude is perceived as:
questions.feedback: Amplitude corresponds to perceived loudness.

questions.question: Hair cells transduce sound by:
questions.feedback: Hair cell deflection opens mechanically gated channels.

questions.question: Tonotopy refers to:
options: Mapping of frequency across auditory structures
questions.feedback: Tonotopy maps sound frequency spatially.

questions.question: Primary auditory cortex is located in the:
questions.feedback: Primary auditory cortex lies in the temporal lobe.
